args:
As Phares and Beren gaze upon the capital,
Harle appears and asks after their true goals.
Seeing through his intentional loss to the
prince, the pair throws the question back,
but Harle says nothing and takes his leave.
H-hold your ground! It's up to us\nto save the capital!
Sir, look! The fog around the palace\nis disappearing!
Then the prince and his retinue\nmust have defeated the Other!
Come on, everyone! If the Other is\nno more, we can make quick work\nof these imperial curs!
Our enemies have rallied! Captain Harle,\nwhat are your... Wait, where's the captain?
I've not seen him for some time.
Ilia damn that man—I KNEW he couldn't\nbe trusted!
From this vantage, even the capital\nappears as some mere plaything.
It is an empty burg o'erflowing with naught\nbut florid bombast—not at all unlike the\nseventh scion, as I think upon it.

This will be our last look at the capital for
some time. And once robbed of its prime
statesperson, Sol Alberia will know
terrible trouble in the days to come.
Thank you, my brother.\nI understand the city well now.
First, we must do something\nabout the man over there.
Ah, yes. I suppose we must.
Razor-sharp as always, Phares.\nNothing ever did get by you.

Please forgive my impropriety for
eavesdropping, though it is a testament
to good fortune that I should happen
upon the pair of you here.
Harle. He once served as chief\nof the Capital Guard.
An honor to finally meet you, Prince Beren.

I must say, it is a moving tale indeed to
hear of an elder brother who risked all
to extract his younger sibling from a
most terrible imprisonment.

I wonder what it was that impelled you to
such action, Prince Phares? You must
have had some intent beyond living up to
that sacred bond of brotherly affections.
Oh, dear me! It seems my foolish musings\nare making themselves known again.\nPray forgive my inapp—
Will he interfere with our work?
Soft, Beren. This man is no threat.
You have my most sincere gratitude\nfor quelling your anger, Prince Beren.
If anyone is plotting something here,\nHarle, it appears to be you.
Oh ho! Whatever do you mean?
One would be hard-pressed to call your\nmagical-barrier defense ＂ironclad.＂
If you were truly putting your heart into\nthe defense, surely you would have\nplanned a more multifaceted strategy.

You observed the battle, did you? Ah,
I confess that I am ashamed of my own
inadequacies in allowing the New Alberian
Army to break through our defenses.
And what of the matter\nof the rebel insurgency?

Surely there is no way one such as you—
a paragon of secret intelligence and
tactics—would be wholly unaware of a
rebel faction operating in your own army.
One might even think you overlooked that\nintentionally in order to permit my brother\nand his forces free access to the capital.
You give me far too much credit,\nPrince Phares—I am but a humble\nservant of the crown.
At my best, I am no more than a knight\nof little renown huddled under the\ngreat tree that is the royal family.
I do not imagine for a moment that\nour family is what you cling to.
I, er...confess myself at a loss.
And yet, I also find it strangely enjoyable!\nClearly I am no match for your keen and\npenetrating insight, My Prince.

I shall take the time to carefully observe
what great works are to come from the
both of you. And with that, I take my leave.
May we meet again in the coming days.
Should we simply let him fly away?
We should. His ＂ability＂ may be of use\nto my research at some point.
But I fear we have tarried long enough;\nwe have a plan to put into motion.
Indeed, there is still much for us to do.
